title: Graphical Summaries
content: Statistics Notebook Paige's Notes Intermediate Statistics (MATH 325) Experimental Design (MATH 326) Applied Linear Regression (MATH 425) R Help R Commands R Markdown Hints Data Sources Example Analyses Describing Data Graphical Summaries Numerical Summaries Making Inference Overview t Tests Wilcoxon Tests Kruskal-Wallis Test ANOVA Linear Regression Logistic Regression Chi-Squared Tests Randomization Analyses 325 Analyses Good Example Analysis Poor Example Analysis Rent Stephanie High School Seniors (Independent Samples t-Test) Recalling Words (Wilcoxon Test) My Two-way ANOVA Food (Kruskal-Wallis Test) My Simple Linear Regression Weather (Multiple Linear Regression) My Logistic Regression My Chi-squared Test Testing Center (Consulting Project) 425 Analyses Predicting Rexburg, Idaho Weather Residuals, Sums of Squares, and R-Squared Acura TL Selling Prices Predicting Grades House Selling Prices Outlier Theory Assignment Homework Focus Graphical Summaries There are many ways to display data. The fundamental idea is that the graphical depiction of data should communicate the truth the data has to offer about the situation of interest. Histograms 1 Quantitative Variable Overview Great for showing the distribution of data for a single quantitative variable when the sample size is large. Dotplots are a good alternative for smaller sample sizes. Gives a good feel for the mean and standard deviation of the data. R Instructions Base R ggplot2 plotly To make a histogram in R use the function: hist(object) object must be quantitative data. R refers to this as a ‚Äúnumeric vector.‚Äù Usually this will be the column of a dataset accessed with the $ sign by hist(dataSetName$columnName). Type ?hist in your R Console to open the help file in R. Example Code Hover your mouse over the example codes to learn more. Click on them to see what they create. Basic histogram hist An R function ‚Äúhist‚Äù used to create a histogram. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. $ The $ allows us to access any variable from the airquality dataset. Temp ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset. )Closing parenthsis for the hist function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. Change Color hist(airquality$Temp,¬† This code was explained in the first example code. col=‚Äúskyblue‚Äù col= allows us to specify the color of the plot using a named color. The name of the color must be placed in quotations. Type ‚Äúcolors()‚Äù in R to see color options. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. Add Titles hist(airquality$Temp This part was explained in the first example code. ,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function. The space after the comma is not required. It just looks nice. col=‚Äúskyblue‚Äùcol= allows us to specify the color of the plot using a named color. The name of the color must be placed in quotations. Type ‚Äúcolors()‚Äù in R to see color options. ,¬† A comma must always be used to separate additional commands. xlab=‚ÄúTemperature‚Äù xlab= stands for ‚Äúx label.‚Äù Use it to specify the text to print on the plot under the x-axis. The desired text must always be in quotations. ,¬† A comma must always be used to separate additional commands. main=‚ÄúLa Guardia Airport Daily Mean Temperatures‚Äù main= lets us specify the ‚Äúmain‚Äù title to be placed above the plot. The desired text must always be placed in quotations. ) Functions must always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. To make a histogram in R using the ggplot approach, first ensure library(ggplot2) is loaded. Then, ggplot(data, aes(x=column)) + ¬†¬†geom_histogram() data is the name of your dataset. column is a column of data from your dataset that is quantitative. The aesthetic helper function aes(x= ) is how you tell the gpplot to make the x-axis become your column of data. The geometry helper function geom_histogram() causes the ggplot to become a histogram. Example Code Hover your mouse over the example codes to learn more. Click on them to see what they create. Basic Histogram ggplot An R function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù used to create a framework for a graphic that will have elements added to it with the + sign. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. ,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function. The space after the comma is not required. It just looks nice. aes( The aes or ‚Äúaesthetics‚Äù function allows you to tell the ggplot how it should appear. This includes things like what the x-axis or y-axis should become. x=Temp ‚Äúx=‚Äù declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic. )Closing parenthsis for the aes function. )Closing parenthsis for the ggplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_histogram() The ‚Äúgeom_histogram()‚Äù function causes the ggplot to become a histogram. There are many other ‚Äúgeom_‚Äù functions that could be used. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. Change Bin Width and Color ggplot An R function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù used to create a framework for a graphic that will have elements added to it with the + sign. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. ,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function. The space after the comma is not required. It just looks nice. aes( The aes or ‚Äúaesthetics‚Äù function allows you to tell the ggplot how it should appear. This includes things like what the x-axis or y-axis should become. x=Temp ‚Äúx=‚Äù declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic. )Closing parenthsis for the aes function. )Closing parenthsis for the ggplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_histogram( The ‚Äúgeom_histogram()‚Äù function causes the ggplot to become a histogram. There are many other ‚Äúgeom_‚Äù functions that could be used. binwidth=5,¬† The ‚Äúbinwidth‚Äù command controls the width of the bars in the histogram. fill=‚Äúskyblue‚Äù, The ‚Äúfill‚Äù command controls the color of the insides of each bar. color=‚Äúblack‚Äù The ‚Äúcolor‚Äù command controls the color of the edges of each bar. )Closing parenthsis for the geom_histogram function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. Add Titles ggplot An R function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù used to create a framework for a graphic that will have elements added to it with the + sign. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. ,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function. The space after the comma is not required. It just looks nice. aes( The aes or ‚Äúaesthetics‚Äù function allows you to tell the ggplot how it should appear. This includes things like what the x-axis or y-axis should become. x=Temp ‚Äúx=‚Äù declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic. )Closing parenthsis for the aes function. )Closing parenthsis for the ggplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_histogram( The ‚Äúgeom_histogram()‚Äù function causes the ggplot to become a histogram. Basic histogram plot_ly An R function ‚Äúplot_ly‚Äù from library(plotly) used to create any plotly plot. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Using a width=2 is probably better. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†%>% The pipe operator passes the completed plot_ly(‚Ä¶) code into the layout(‚Ä¶) function. layout( The layout(‚Ä¶) function is used for specifying details about the axes and their labels. title=‚ÄúLa Guardia Airport Daily Mean Temperatures‚Äù This declares a main title for the top of the graph. xaxis=list( This declares a list of options to be specified for the xaxis. The same can be done for the yaxis(‚Ä¶). title=‚ÄúTemperature in Degrees F‚Äù This declares a title underneath the x-axis. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. Explanation Histograms group data that are close to each other into ‚Äúbins‚Äù (the vertical bars in the plot). The height of a bin is determined by the number of data points that are contained within the bin. For example, if we group together all the sections of the book of scripture known as the Doctrine and Covenants that occurred in a given year (Jan.¬†1st - Dec.¬†31st) then we get the following counts. Year Number of Sections 1823 1 1824 0 1825 0 1826 0 1827 0 1828 1 1829 16 1830 19 1831 37 1832 16 1833 12 1834 5 1835 3 1836 4 1837 1 1838 8 1839 3 1840 0 1841 3 1842 2 1843

The fundamental idea is that the graphical depiction of data should communicate the truth the data has to offer about the situation of interest.
Histograms 1 Quantitative Variable Overview Great for showing the distribution of data for a single quantitative variable when the sample size is large.
Dotplots are a good alternative for smaller sample sizes.
Gives a good feel for the mean and standard deviation of the data.
R Instructions Base R ggplot2 plotly To make a histogram in R use the function: hist(object) object must be quantitative data.
R refers to this as a ‚Äúnumeric vector.‚Äù Usually this will be the column of a dataset accessed with the $ sign by hist(dataSetName$columnName).
Type ?hist in your R Console to open the help file in R.
Example Code Hover your mouse over the example codes to learn more.
Click on them to see what they create.
Basic histogram hist An R function ‚Äúhist‚Äù used to create a histogram.
( Parenthesis to begin the function.
Must touch the last letter of the function.
airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset.
Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it.
$ The $ allows us to access any variable from the airquality dataset.
Temp ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset.
)Closing parenthsis for the hist function.
¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code.
¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output.

col=‚Äúskyblue‚Äù col= allows us to specify the color of the plot using a named color.
The name of the color must be placed in quotations.
Type ‚Äúcolors()‚Äù in R to see color options.
) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis.
¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code.

,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function.
The space after the comma is not required.
It just looks nice.
col=‚Äúskyblue‚Äùcol= allows us to specify the color of the plot using a named color.
The name of the color must be placed in quotations.
Type ‚Äúcolors()‚Äù in R to see color options.
,¬† A comma must always be used to separate additional commands.
xlab=‚ÄúTemperature‚Äù xlab= stands for ‚Äúx label.‚Äù Use it to specify the text to print on the plot under the x-axis.
The desired text must always be in quotations.
,¬† A comma must always be used to separate additional commands.
main=‚ÄúLa Guardia Airport Daily Mean Temperatures‚Äù main= lets us specify the ‚Äúmain‚Äù title to be placed above the plot.
The desired text must always be placed in quotations.

¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code.
¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output.
To make a histogram in R using the ggplot approach, first ensure library(ggplot2) is loaded.
Then, ggplot(data, aes(x=column)) + ¬†¬†geom_histogram() data is the name of your dataset.
column is a column of data from your dataset that is quantitative.
The aesthetic helper function aes(x= ) is how you tell the gpplot to make the x-axis become your column of data.
The geometry helper function geom_histogram() causes the ggplot to become a histogram.
Example Code Hover your mouse over the example codes to learn more.
Click on them to see what they create.

title: üìç Explanation
content: Explanation Histograms group data that are close to each other into ‚Äúbins‚Äù (the vertical bars in the plot). The height of a bin is determined by the number of data points that are contained within the bin. For example, if we group together all the sections of the book of scripture known as the Doctrine and Covenants that occurred in a given year (Jan.¬†1st - Dec.¬†31st) then we get the following counts. Year Number of Sections 1823 1 1824 0 1825 0 1826 0 1827 0 1828 1 1829 16 1830 19 1831 37 1832 16 1833 12 1834 5 1835 3 1836 4 1837 1 1838 8 1839 3 1840 0 1841 3 1842 2 1843 4 1844 1 1845 0 1846 0 1847 1 *Note that Section 138 occurred in 1918 and is removed from this example. In this example, each ‚Äúbin‚Äù spans 365 days (Jan.¬†1 - Dec.¬†31 of each year). Since ‚Äúdates‚Äù can be used as quantitative data, it makes sense to make a histogram of these data. (Remember, histograms are only for quantitative data.) Notice in the bins above that the left edge of the bin is on the year the data corresponds with. The right edge of the bin lands on the following year. For example, the first bin has left edge on 1823 and right edge on 1824. Since there was one revelation in 1823, this bin has a height of 1. The bin that has 1831 on the left and 1832 on the right shows that 37 revelations occurred in 1831. It is powerful to notice the amount of revelations occurring around 1830, the year the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints was organized.

title: üìç Boxplots
content: Boxplots 1 Quantitative Variable | 2+ Groups Overview Graphical depiction of the five-number summary. Great for comparing the distributions of data across several groups or categories. Provides a quick visual understanding of the location of the median as well as the range of the data. Can be useful in showing outliers. Sample size should be larger than at least five, or computing the five-number summary is not very meaningful. Side-by-side dotplots are a good alternative for smaller sample sizes. R Instructions Base R ggplot2 plotly To make a boxplot in R use the function: boxplot(object) To make side-by-side boxplots: boxplot(object ~ group, data=NameOfYourData, ...) object must be quantitative data. R refers to this as a ‚Äúnumeric vector.‚Äù group must be qualitative data. R refers to this as either a ‚Äúcharacter vector‚Äù or a ‚Äúfactor.‚Äù However, a ‚Äúnumeric vector‚Äù can also act as a qualitative variable. NameOfYourData is the name of the dataset containing object and group. implies there are many other options that can be given to the boxplot() function. Type ?boxplot in your R Console for more details. Example Code Basic Single Boxplot boxplot An R function ‚Äúboxplot‚Äù used to create boxplots. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. $ The $ allows us to access any variable from the airquality dataset. Temp ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset. )Closing parenthsis for the function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. More Useful‚Ä¶ Basic Side-by-Side Boxplot boxplot An R function ‚Äúboxplot‚Äù used to create boxplots. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. Temp ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset. ¬†~¬† The ~ is used to tell R that you want one boxplot of the quantitative variable (‚ÄúTemp‚Äù) for each group found in the qualitative variable (‚ÄúMonth‚Äù). Month ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù is a qualitative variable (in this case a ‚Äúnumeric vector‚Äù defining months by 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the ‚Äúboxplot()‚Äù function. data=airquality data= is used to tell R that the ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù variables are located in the airquality dataset. Without this, R will not know where to find ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù and the command will give an error. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. Add Names under each Box boxplot An R function ‚Äúboxplot‚Äù used to create boxplots. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. Temp ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset. ¬†~¬† The ~ is used to tell R that you want one boxplot of the quantitative variable (‚ÄúTemp‚Äù) for each group found in the qualitative variable (‚ÄúMonth‚Äù). Month ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù is a qualitative variable (in this case a ‚Äúnumeric vector‚Äù defining months by 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the ‚Äúboxplot()‚Äù function. data=airquality data= is used to tell R that the ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù variables are located in the airquality dataset. Without this, R will not know where to find ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù and the command will give an error. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the ‚Äúboxplot()‚Äù function. names=c(‚ÄúMay‚Äù,‚ÄúJune‚Äù,‚ÄúJuly‚Äù,‚ÄúAug‚Äù,‚ÄúSep‚Äù) names= is used to tell R what labels to place on the x-axis below each boxplot. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. Add Color and Labels boxplot(Temp ~ Month, data=airquality This code was explained in the previous example code. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. xlab=‚ÄúMonth of the Year‚Äù xlab= stands for ‚Äúx label.‚Äù Use it to specify the text to print on the plot under the x-axis. The desired text must always be contained in quotes. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. ylab=‚ÄúTemperature‚Äù ylab= stands for ‚Äúy label.‚Äù Use it to specify the text to print on the plot next to the y-axis. The desired text must always be contained in quotes. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. main=‚ÄúLa Guardia Airport Daily Temperatures‚Äù main= stands for the ‚Äúmain label‚Äù of the plot, which is placed at the top center of the plot. The desired text must always be contained in quotes. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. col=‚Äúwheat‚Äù col= stands for the ‚Äúcolor‚Äù of the plot. The color name ‚Äúwheat‚Äù is an available color in R. Type colors() in the R Console to see more options. The color name must always be placed in quotes. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. To make a boxplot in R using the ggplot approach, first ensure library(ggplot2) is loaded. Then, ggplot(data, aes(x=groupsColumn, y=dataColumn) + ¬†¬†geom_boxplot() data is the name of your dataset. groupsColumn is a column of data from your dataset that is qualitative and represents the groups that should each have a boxplot. dataColumn is a column of data from your dataset that is quantitative. The aesthetic helper function aes(x= , y=) is how you tell the gpplot to make the x-axis have the values in your groupsColumn of data, the y-axis become your dataColumn. Note if groupsColumn is not a factor, use factor(groupsColumn) instead. The geometry helper function geom_boxplot() causes the ggplot to become a boxplot. Example Code Basic Single Boxplot ggplot An R function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù used to create a framework for a graphic that will have elements added to it with the + sign. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. R refers to this as a ‚Äúnumeric vector.‚Äù This will become the y-axis of the plot. columnNameX must be the name of a column of qualitative data. This will provide the ‚Äúgroups‚Äù forming each individual box in the boxplot. type="box" tells the plot_ly(‚Ä¶) function to create a boxplot. Visit plotly.com/r/box-plots for more details. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. y= The y= allows us to declare which column of the data set will become the y-axis of the boxplot. In other words, the quantitative data we are interested in studying for each group. ~Temp, ¬† ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset. In other words, the ‚Äúgroups‚Äù forming each separate box in the boxplot. ~as.factor(Month), ¬† since ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset we have to change it to a ‚Äúfactor‚Äù which forces R to treat it as a qualitative (groups) variable. The ~ is required before column names inside all plot_ly(‚Ä¶) commands. type=‚Äúbox‚Äù This option tells the plot_ly(‚Ä¶) function what ‚Äútype‚Äù of graph to make. sentences: 1 Quantitative Variable | 2+ Groups
Overview Graphical depiction of the five-number summary.
Great for comparing the distributions of data across several groups or categories.
Provides a quick visual understanding of the location of the median as well as the range of the data.
Can be useful in showing outliers.
Sample size should be larger than at least five, or computing the five-number summary is not very meaningful.
Side-by-side dotplots are a good alternative for smaller sample sizes.

R Instructions Base R ggplot2 plotly To make a boxplot in R use the function: boxplot(object) To make side-by-side boxplots: boxplot(object ~ group, data=NameOfYourData, ...) object must be quantitative data.
R refers to this as a ‚Äúnumeric vector.‚Äù group must be qualitative data.
R refers to this as either a ‚Äúcharacter vector‚Äù or a ‚Äúfactor.‚Äù However, a ‚Äúnumeric vector‚Äù can also act as a qualitative variable.

content: Overview Graphical depiction of the five-number summary. Great for comparing the distributions of data across several groups or categories. Provides a quick visual understanding of the location of the median as well as the range of the data. Can be useful in showing outliers. Sample size should be larger than at least five, or computing the five-number summary is not very meaningful. Side-by-side dotplots are a good alternative for smaller sample sizes.

content: R Instructions Base R ggplot2 plotly To make a boxplot in R use the function: boxplot(object) To make side-by-side boxplots: boxplot(object ~ group, data=NameOfYourData, ...) object must be quantitative data. R refers to this as a ‚Äúnumeric vector.‚Äù group must be qualitative data. R refers to this as either a ‚Äúcharacter vector‚Äù or a ‚Äúfactor.‚Äù However, a ‚Äúnumeric vector‚Äù can also act as a qualitative variable. NameOfYourData is the name of the dataset containing object and group. implies there are many other options that can be given to the boxplot() function. Type ?boxplot in your R Console for more details. Example Code Basic Single Boxplot boxplot An R function ‚Äúboxplot‚Äù used to create boxplots. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. $ The $ allows us to access any variable from the airquality dataset. Temp ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset. )Closing parenthsis for the function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. Month ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù is a qualitative variable (in this case a ‚Äúnumeric vector‚Äù defining months by 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the ‚Äúboxplot()‚Äù function. data=airquality data= is used to tell R that the ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù variables are located in the airquality dataset. Without this, R will not know where to find ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù and the command will give an error. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. The desired text must always be contained in quotes. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. ylab=‚ÄúTemperature‚Äù ylab= stands for ‚Äúy label.‚Äù Use it to specify the text to print on the plot next to the y-axis. The desired text must always be contained in quotes. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. main=‚ÄúLa Guardia Airport Daily Temperatures‚Äù main= stands for the ‚Äúmain label‚Äù of the plot, which is placed at the top center of the plot. To make a boxplot in R using the ggplot approach, first ensure library(ggplot2) is loaded. Then, ggplot(data, aes(x=groupsColumn, y=dataColumn) + ¬†¬†geom_boxplot() data is the name of your dataset. groupsColumn is a column of data from your dataset that is qualitative and represents the groups that should each have a boxplot. dataColumn is a column of data from your dataset that is quantitative. The aesthetic helper function aes(x= , y=) is how you tell the gpplot to make the x-axis have the values in your groupsColumn of data, the y-axis become your dataColumn. Note if groupsColumn is not a factor, use factor(groupsColumn) instead. The geometry helper function geom_boxplot() causes the ggplot to become a boxplot. Change Color plot_ly(airquality, y=~Temp, x=~as.factor(Month), type=‚Äúbox‚Äù,¬† This code was explained in the first example code. fillcolor=‚Äúskyblue‚Äù,¬† this changes the fill color of the boxes in the boxplot to the color specified, in this case ‚Äúskyblue.‚Äù line=list(color=‚Äúdarkgray‚Äù, width=3),¬† this ‚Äúlist(‚Ä¶)‚Äù of options that will be specified will effect the edges of the boxes in the boxplot. We are changing their color to ‚Äúdarkgray‚Äù and their width to 3 pixels wide. marker=list( this ‚Äúlist(‚Ä¶)‚Äù of options that will be specified will effect the outlying dots shown in the boxplots beyond the ‚Äúfences‚Äù of each box. color = ‚Äúorange‚Äù,¬† this will change the color of the dots to orange. line = list(,¬† this opens a list of options to specify for the ‚Äúlines‚Äù around the ‚Äúmarkers.‚Äù color = ‚Äúred‚Äù,¬† this will change the color of the lines around the outlier dots to red. width = 1 this will change the width of the lines around the outlier dots to 1 pixel. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. Add Titles plot_ly(airquality, y=~Temp, x=~as.factor(Month), type=‚Äúbox‚Äù, fillcolor=‚Äúskyblue‚Äù, line=list(color=‚Äúdarkgray‚Äù, width=3), marker = list(color=‚Äúorange‚Äù, line = list(color=‚Äúred‚Äù, width=1)))¬† This code was explained in the above example code. %>% the pipe operator sends the completed plot_ly(‚Ä¶) code into the layout function. layout( The layout(‚Ä¶) function is used for specifying details about the axes and their labels. title=‚ÄúLa Guardia Airport Daily Mean Temperatures‚Äù This declares a main title for the top of the graph. xaxis=list( This declares a list of options to be specified for the xaxis. The same can be done for the yaxis(‚Ä¶). title=‚ÄúMonth of the Year‚Äù This declares a title underneath the x-axis. ),¬† Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. yaxis=list( This declares a list of options to be specified for the y-axis. title=‚ÄúTemperature in Degrees F‚Äù This declares a title beside the y-axis. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output.

R refers to this as a ‚Äúnumeric vector.‚Äù group must be qualitative data.
R refers to this as either a ‚Äúcharacter vector‚Äù or a ‚Äúfactor.‚Äù However, a ‚Äúnumeric vector‚Äù can also act as a qualitative variable.
NameOfYourData is the name of the dataset containing object and group.
implies there are many other options that can be given to the boxplot() function.
Type ?boxplot in your R Console for more details.

title: üìç Explanation
content: Explanation Understanding how a boxplot is created is the best way to understand what the boxplot shows. How Boxplots are Made The five-number summary is computed. A box is drawn with one edge located at the first quartile and the opposite edge located at the third quartile. This box is then divided into two boxes by placing another line inside the box at the location of the median. The maximum value and minimum value are marked on the plot. Whiskers are drawn from the first quartile out towards the minimum and from the third quartile out towards the maximum. If the minimum or maximum is too far away, then the whisker is ended early. Any points beyond the line ending the whisker are marked on the plot as dots. This helps identify possible outliers in the data.
sentences: Understanding how a boxplot is created is the best way to understand what the boxplot shows.
How Boxplots are Made The five-number summary is computed.
A box is drawn with one edge located at the first quartile and the opposite edge located at the third quartile.
This box is then divided into two boxes by placing another line inside the box at the location of the median.
The maximum value and minimum value are marked on the plot.
Whiskers are drawn from the first quartile out towards the minimum and from the third quartile out towards the maximum.
If the minimum or maximum is too far away, then the whisker is ended early.
Any points beyond the line ending the whisker are marked on the plot as dots.
This helps identify possible outliers in the data.

title: üìç Dot Plots
content: Dot Plots 1 Quantitative Variable | 2+ Groups Overview Depicts the actual values of each data point. Best for small sample sizes or for datasets where there are lots of repeated values. Histograms or boxplots are better alternatives for large sample sizes when there are few repeated values. Great for comparing the distribution of data across several groups or categories. R Instructions Base R ggplot2 plotly To make a dot plot in Base R use the code: stripchart(object) For side-by-side dotplots: stripchart(object ~ group, data=NameOfYourData) object must be a quantitative (or ordinal) variable, what R refers to as a ‚Äúnumeric vector.‚Äù group is a qualitative variable, which in R can be either a ‚Äúcharacter vector‚Äù or a ‚Äúfactor.‚Äù NameOfYourData is the name of the dataset containing object and group. Example Code stripchart An R function ‚Äústripchart‚Äù used to create a dot plot. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. $ The $ allows us to access any variable from the airquality dataset. Temp ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the function. method=‚Äústack‚Äùmethod= allows us to choose from the options ‚Äúoverplot‚Äù, ‚Äújitter‚Äù, and ‚Äústack‚Äù. The ‚Äústack‚Äù option stacks mutliple points that occur at the same location on top of each other. You can try the code yourself to see what ‚Äúoverplot‚Äù and ‚Äújitter‚Äù do. )Closing parenthsis for the function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. stripchart An R function ‚Äústripchart‚Äù used to create dot plots. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. Temp ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset. ¬†~¬† The ~ is used to tell R that you want a dot plot of the quantitative variable (‚ÄúTemp‚Äù) for each group found in the qualitative variable (‚ÄúMonth‚Äù). Month ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù is a qualitative variable (in this case a ‚Äúnumeric vector‚Äù defining months by 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the function. data=airquality data= is used to tell R that the ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù variables are located in the airquality dataset. Without this, R will not know where to find ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù and the command will give an error. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the function. method=‚Äústack‚Äùmethod= allows us to choose from the options ‚Äúoverplot‚Äù, ‚Äújitter‚Äù, and ‚Äústack‚Äù. The ‚Äústack‚Äù option stacks mutliple points that occur at the same location on top of each other. You can try the code yourself to see what ‚Äúoverplot‚Äù and ‚Äújitter‚Äù do. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. stripchart(Temp ~ Month This part of the code was explained already in the example code directly above this one. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the function. data=airquality data= is used to tell R that the ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù variables are located in the airquality dataset. Without this, R will not know where to find ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù and the command will give an error. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the function. method=‚Äústack‚Äùmethod= allows us to choose from the options ‚Äúoverplot‚Äù, ‚Äújitter‚Äù, and ‚Äústack‚Äù. The ‚Äústack‚Äù option stacks mutliple points that occur at the same location on top of each other. You can try the code yourself to see what ‚Äúoverplot‚Äù and ‚Äújitter‚Äù do. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. ylab=‚ÄúMonth of the Year‚Äù ylab= stands for ‚Äúy label.‚Äù Use it to specify the text to print on the plot next to the y-axis. The desired text must always be contained in quotes. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. xlab=‚ÄúTemperature‚Äù xlab= stands for ‚Äúx label.‚Äù Use it to specify the text to print on the plot below the x-axis. The desired text must always be contained in quotes. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. main=‚ÄúLa Guardia Airport Daily Temperatures‚Äù main= stands for the ‚Äúmain label‚Äù of the plot, which is placed at the top center of the plot. The desired text must always be contained in quotes. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. col=‚Äúsienna‚Äù col= stands for the ‚Äúcolor‚Äù of the plot. The color name ‚Äúsienna‚Äù is an available color in R. Type colors() in the R Console to see more options. The color name must always be placed in quotes. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. pch=16 pch= stands for the ‚Äúplotting character‚Äù of the plot. This plot uses the filled circle (option 16) as the plotting character. The options are 0, 1, 2, ‚Ä¶, 25. Type ?pch in the R Console, and scroll down the help file half way to see what each option does. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. To make a dot plot in R using the ggplot approach, first ensure: library(ggplot2) is loaded. Then, ggplot(data, aes(x=groupsColumn, y=dataColumn) + ¬†¬†geom_dotplot() data is the name of your dataset. groupsColumn is a column of data from your dataset that is qualitative and represents the groups that should each have a boxplot. dataColumn is a column of data from your dataset that is quantitative. The aesthetic helper function aes(x= , y=) is how you tell the gpplot to make the x-axis have the values in your groupsColumn of data, the y-axis become your dataColumn. Note if groupsColumn is not a factor, use factor(groupsColumn) instead. The geometry helper function geom_dotplot() causes the ggplot to become a dot plot. Example Code Click to view. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. ,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function. The space after the comma is not required. It just looks nice. aes( The aes or ‚Äúaesthetics‚Äù function allows you to tell the ggplot how it should appear. This includes things like what the y-axis should become. x=Temp ‚Äúx=‚Äù declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic. )Closing parenthsis for the aes function. )Closing parenthsis for the ggplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_dotplot() The ‚Äúgeom_dotplot()‚Äù function causes the ggplot to become a dot plot. There are many other ‚Äúgeom_‚Äù functions that could be used. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. ggplot An R function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù used to create a framework for a graphic that will have elements added to it with the + sign. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. ,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function. The space after the comma is not required. It just looks nice. aes( The aes or ‚Äúaesthetics‚Äù function allows you to tell the ggplot how it should appear. This includes things like what the x-axis or y-axis should become. x=factor(Month),¬† ‚Äúx=‚Äù declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic. Use factor(Month) to change ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù, which is numeric, into categories. y=Temp ‚Äúy=‚Äù declares which variable will become the y-axis of the graphic. )Closing parenthsis for the aes function. )Closing parenthsis for the ggplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_dotplot( The ‚Äúgeom_dotplot()‚Äù function causes the ggplot to become a dot plot. There are many other ‚Äúgeom_‚Äù functions that could be used. binaxis = ‚Äúy‚Äù,¬† This tells the function that the y=Temp statement should be used as the quantitative data. stackdir = ‚Äúup‚Äù,¬† This causes the dots to be stacked on top of each other. position = ‚Äúdodge‚Äù,¬† This causes the dots to not overalap, i.e., ‚Äúdodge each other.‚Äù dotsize = 0.75,¬† Controls the size of the dots. You can make them larger with numbers greater than 1 and smaller with numbers less than 1. binwidth = 0.5 Controls how the dots are grouped, similar to the bins in a histogram. )Closing parenthsis for the geom_dotplot function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. ggplot An R function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù used to create a framework for a graphic that will have elements added to it with the + sign. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. ,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function. The space after the comma is not required. It just looks nice. aes( The aes or ‚Äúaesthetics‚Äù function allows you to tell the ggplot how it should appear. This includes things like what the x-axis or y-axis should become. x=factor(Month),¬† ‚Äúx=‚Äù declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic. Use factor(Month) to change ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù, which is numeric, into categories. y=Temp ‚Äúy=‚Äù declares which variable will become the y-axis of the graphic. )Closing parenthsis for the aes function. )Closing parenthsis for the ggplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† coord_flip( ) The ‚Äúcoord_flip()‚Äù function causes the ggplot to reverse the axes when drawing the plot. However, all commands must be given as if the plot were to be drawn without coord_flip(), then coord_flip() is applied. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_dotplot( The ‚Äúgeom_dotplot()‚Äù function causes the ggplot to become a dot plot. You can make them larger with numbers greater than 1 and smaller with numbers less than 1. binwidth = 0.5 Controls how the dots are grouped, similar to the bins in a histogram. )Closing parenthsis for the geom_dotplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† labs( The ‚Äúlabs‚Äù function is used to add labels to the plot, like a main title, x-label and y-label. title=‚ÄúLa Guardia Airport Daily Mean Temperature‚Äù,¬† The ‚Äútitle=‚Äù command allows you to control the main title at the top of the graphic. x=‚ÄúMonth of the Year‚Äù,¬† The ‚Äúx=‚Äù command allows you to control the x-label of the graphic. y=‚ÄúDaily Mean Temperature‚Äù The ‚Äúy=‚Äù command allows you to control the y-label of the graphic. )Closing parenthsis for the labs function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. There are many other ‚Äúgeom_‚Äù functions that could be used. binaxis = ‚Äúy‚Äù,¬† This tells the function that the y=Temp statement should be used as the quantitative data. stackdir = ‚Äúup‚Äù,¬† This causes the dots to be stacked on top of each other. position = ‚Äúdodge‚Äù,¬† This causes the dots to not overalap, i.e., ‚Äúdodge each other.‚Äù dotsize = 0.75,¬† Controls the size of the dots. You can make them larger with numbers greater than 1 and smaller with numbers less than 1. binwidth = 0.5 Controls how the dots are grouped, similar to the bins in a histogram. )Closing parenthsis for the geom_dotplot function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. ggplot An R function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù used to create a framework for a graphic that will have elements added to it with the + sign. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. However, all commands must be given as if the plot were to be drawn without coord_flip(), then coord_flip() is applied. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_dotplot( The ‚Äúgeom_dotplot()‚Äù function causes the ggplot to become a dot plot. sentences: Base R ggplot2 plotly To make a dot plot in Base R use the code: stripchart(object) For side-by-side dotplots: stripchart(object ~ group, data=NameOfYourData) object must be a quantitative (or ordinal) variable, what R refers to as a ‚Äúnumeric vector.‚Äù group is a qualitative variable, which in R can be either a ‚Äúcharacter vector‚Äù or a ‚Äúfactor.‚Äù NameOfYourData is the name of the dataset containing object and group.
Example Code stripchart An R function ‚Äústripchart‚Äù used to create a dot plot.
( Parenthesis to begin the function.

method=‚Äústack‚Äùmethod= allows us to choose from the options ‚Äúoverplot‚Äù, ‚Äújitter‚Äù, and ‚Äústack‚Äù.

title: üìç Scatterplots
content: Scatterplots 2 Quantitative Variables Overview Depicts the actual values of the data points, which are \((x,y)\) pairs. Works well for small or large sample sizes. Visualizes well the correlation between the two variables. Should be used in linear regression contexts whenever possible. R Instructions Base R ggplot2 plotly To make a scatterplot in R use the code: plot(y ~ x, data=NameOfYourData) y is the quantitative response variable, i.e., ‚Äúnumeric vector.‚Äù x is the quantitative explanatory variable, i.e., ‚Äúnumeric vector.‚Äù NameOfYourData is the name of the dataset containing y and x. Note: plot(object) where object is a ‚Äúnumeric vector‚Äù will create a time series plot, which is sometimes useful. Example Code plot An R function ‚Äúplot‚Äù used to create a scatterplot, or in this case a time series plot because only one quantitative variable is being supplied to the function. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. $ The $ allows us to access any variable from the airquality dataset. Temp ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the function. type=‚Äúl‚Äùtype= allows us to choose from the options ‚Äúp‚Äù for points, ‚Äúl‚Äù for lines, and ‚Äúb‚Äù for both. There are also other options that could be chosen, type¬† ?plot in the R Console to learn about them. )Closing parenthsis for the function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. plot An R function ‚Äúplot‚Äù used to create a scatterplot. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. Temp ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset that is being used as the response variable (y-axis) for this plot. ¬†~¬† The ~ is used to tell R that you want a scatterplot with the quantitative variable ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù on the y-axis and the qauntitative variable ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù on the x-axis. Wind ‚ÄúWind‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset that is being used as the explanatory variable (x-axis) for this plot. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the function. data=airquality data= is used to tell R that the ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù variables are located in the airquality dataset. Without this, R will not know where to find ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù and the command will give an error. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the function. pch=8 pch= stands for the ‚Äúplotting character‚Äù of the plot. This plot uses the star shape (option 8) as the plotting character. The options are 0, 1, 2, ‚Ä¶, 25. Type ?pch in the R Console, and scroll down the help file half way to see what each option does. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. plot(Temp ~ Wind This part of the code was explained already in the example code directly above this one. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the function. data=airquality data= is used to tell R that the ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù variables are located in the airquality dataset. Without this, R will not know where to find ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù and ‚ÄúMonth‚Äù and the command will give an error. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the function. xlab=‚ÄúDaily Wind Speed (mph)‚Äù xlab= stands for ‚Äúx label.‚Äù Use it to specify the text to print on the plot below the x-axis. The desired text must always be contained in quotes. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. ylab=‚ÄúTemperature‚Äù ylab= stands for ‚Äúy label.‚Äù Use it to specify the text to print on the plot next to the y-axis. The desired text must always be contained in quotes. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. main=‚ÄúLa Guardia Airport (May - Sep)‚Äù main= stands for the ‚Äúmain label‚Äù of the plot, which is placed at the top center of the plot. The desired text must always be contained in quotes. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. col=‚Äúivory3‚Äù col= stands for the ‚Äúcolor‚Äù of the plot. The color name ‚Äúivory3‚Äù is an available color in R. Type colors() in the R Console to see more options. The color name must always be placed in quotes. ,¬† The comma is used to separate each additional command to a function. pch=18 pch= stands for the ‚Äúplotting character‚Äù of the plot. This plot uses the filled diamond (option 18) as the plotting character. The options are 0, 1, 2, ‚Ä¶, 25. Type ?pch in the R Console, and scroll down the help file half way to see what each option does. ) Functions always end with a closing parenthesis. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. pch Options To make a scatterplot in R using the ggplot approach, first ensure: library(ggplot2) is loaded. Then, ggplot(data, aes(x=dataColumn1, y=dataColumn2) + ¬†¬†geom_point() data is the name of your dataset. dataColumn1 is a column of data from your dataset that is quantitative and will be used as the explanatory variable. dataColumn2 is a column of data from your dataset that is quantitative and will be used as the response variable. The aesthetic helper function aes(x= , y=) is how you tell the gpplot to make the x-axis have the values in your dataColumn1 of data, the y-axis become your dataColumn2. The geometry helper function geom_point() causes the ggplot to become a scatterplot. Example Code Click to view. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. ,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function. The space after the comma is not required. It just looks nice. aes( The aes or ‚Äúaesthetics‚Äù function allows you to tell the ggplot how it should appear. This includes things like what the x-axis or y-axis should become. x=Wind,¬† ‚Äúx=‚Äù declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic, the explanatory variable. y=Temp ‚Äúy=‚Äù declares which variable will become the y-axis of the graphic. )Closing parenthsis for the aes function. )Closing parenthsis for the ggplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_point( The ‚Äúgeom_point()‚Äù function causes the ggplot to become a scatterplot. There are many other ‚Äúgeom_‚Äù functions that could be used. )Closing parenthsis for the geom_point function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. ggplot An R function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù used to create a framework for a graphic that will have elements added to it with the + sign. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it. ,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function. The space after the comma is not required. It just looks nice. aes( The aes or ‚Äúaesthetics‚Äù function allows you to tell the ggplot how it should appear. This includes things like what the x-axis or y-axis should become. x=Wind,¬† ‚Äúx=‚Äù declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic, the explanatory variable. y=Temp ‚Äúy=‚Äù declares which variable will become the y-axis of the graphic. )Closing parenthsis for the aes function. )Closing parenthsis for the ggplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_point( The ‚Äúgeom_point()‚Äù function causes the ggplot to become a scatterplot. There are many other ‚Äúgeom_‚Äù functions that could be used. color = ‚Äúivory3‚Äù,¬† Controls the color of the dots. pch = 18 Controls the type of plotting character to be used in the plot. )Closing parenthsis for the geom_point function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† labs( The ‚Äúlabs‚Äù function is used to add labels to the plot, like a main title, x-label and y-label. title=‚ÄúLa Guardia Airport (May - Sep)‚Äù,¬† The ‚Äútitle=‚Äù command allows you to control the main title at the top of the graphic. x=‚ÄúDaily Average Wind Speed (mph)‚Äù,¬† The ‚Äúx=‚Äù command allows you to control the x-label of the graphic. y=‚ÄúDaily Mean Temperature‚Äù The ‚Äúy=‚Äù command allows you to control the y-label of the graphic. )Closing parenthsis for the labs function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬†theme_bw()Changes the ‚Äútheme‚Äù or look of the plot to ‚Äúblack‚Äù and ‚Äúwhite‚Äù. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. To make a scatterplot in R using the plotly approach, first ensure: library(plotly) is loaded. Then, plot_ly(data, x= ~dataColumn1, y= ~dataColumn2) data is the name of your dataset. dataColumn1 is a column of data from your dataset that is quantitative and will be used as the explanatory variable. dataColumn2 is a column of data from your dataset that is quantitative and will be used as the response variable. Example Code plot_ly(airquality, x= ~Wind, y= ~Temp) plot_ly(KidsFeet, x= ~length, y= ~width, color= ~sex, size= ~birthmonth, text= ~paste("Name:", name, "\n", "Birth-Month:", birthmonth), colors=c("skyblue","hotpink")) %>% layout(title="KidsFeet dataset", xaxis=list(title="Length of the longer foot in cm"), yaxis=list(title="Width of the longer foot in cm"))

Note: plot(object) where object is a ‚Äúnumeric vector‚Äù will create a time series plot, which is sometimes useful.
Example Code plot An R function ‚Äúplot‚Äù used to create a scatterplot, or in this case a time series plot because only one quantitative variable is being supplied to the function.
( Parenthesis to begin the function.
Must touch the last letter of the function.
airquality ‚Äúairquality‚Äù is a dataset.
Type ‚ÄúView(airquality)‚Äù in R to see it.
$ The $ allows us to access any variable from the airquality dataset.
Temp ‚ÄúTemp‚Äù is a quantitative variable (numeric vector) from the ‚Äúairquality‚Äù dataset.
,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the function.

title: üìç Bar Charts
content: Bar Charts 1 (or 2) Qualitative Variable(s) Overview Depicts the number of occurrances for each category, or level, of the qualitative variable. Similar to a histogram, but there is no natural way to order the bars. Thus the white-space between each bar. It is called a Pareto chart if the bars are ordered from tallest to shortest. Clustered and stacked bar charts are often used to display information for two qualitative variables simultaneously. R Instructions Base R ggplot2 plotly To make a bar chart in R use the code: barplot(heights) heights must be a ‚Äúnumeric vector‚Äù that contains the heights for each bar that will be drawn in the plot. Note: both the c() and table() functions can be used to specify the heights. The example codes below demonstrate. Example Code Using the c() function. barplot barplot is an R function used to create a bar chart. ( Parenthesis to begin the barplot function. Must touch the last letter of the function. c c is an R function used to concatenate a list of values together into a ‚Äúvector.‚Äù It is being used here to specify the heights of the 4 bars in the bar plot. ( Parenthesis to begin the c function. Must touch the last letter of the function. 10,5,28,3 This list of numbers will be joined together into a single ‚Äúvector.‚Äù There is no limit on the number of entries that can be put into such a list. )Closing parenthsis for the c() function. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the barplot function. col=‚Äúgray24‚Äù col= stands for the ‚Äúcolor‚Äù of the plot. The color name ‚Äúgray24‚Äù is an available color in R. Type colors() in the R Console to see more options. The color name must always be placed in quotes. )Closing parenthsis for the barplot function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. barplot barplot is an R function used to create a bar chart. ( Parenthesis to begin the barplot function. Must touch the last letter of the function. c c is an R function used to concatenate a list of values together into a ‚Äúvector.‚Äù It is being used here to specify the heights of the 4 bars in the bar plot. ( Parenthesis to begin the c function. Must touch the last letter of the function. Pigs=10,Cats=5,Dogs=28,Roosters=3 This named list of numbers will be joined together into a single ‚Äúvector.‚Äù There is no limit on the number of entries that can be put into such a list. Notice how the names show up as the labels for each bin in the bar chart. )Closing parenthsis for the c() function. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the barplot function. col=‚Äúgray44‚Äù col= stands for the ‚Äúcolor‚Äù of the plot. The color name ‚Äúgray44‚Äù is an available color in R. Type colors() in the R Console to see more options. The color name must always be placed in quotes. )Closing parenthsis for the barplot function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. barplot( barplot is an R function used to create a bar chart. rbind( rbind stands for ‚Äúrow bind‚Äù and is a function that joins together different c() vectors to make them become rows of a table. `Farm 1`=c(Pigs=10,Cats=5,Dogs=28,Roosters=3) Notice how this c() vector of named values is being named ‚ÄúFarm 1.‚Äù The tick marks ` ` are required to specify a name of a vector that has a space in it. If the name was just Farm1 (without a space) then the tick marks would not be needed. Since `Farm 1` is the first vector in the rbind() function, it will become the first row of the resulting table that rbind() will create. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to specify additional c() vectors for the rbind() function. `Farm 2`=c(Pigs=15,Cats=3,Dogs=8,Roosters=1) Notice how this c() vector of named values is being named ‚ÄúFarm 2.‚Äù It will become the second row of the table created by rbind(). )Closing parenthsis for the rbind() function. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to specify additional commands for the barplot function. col=c(‚Äúgray84‚Äù,‚Äúgray44‚Äù) col= stands for the ‚Äúcolor‚Äù of the plot. Here two colors: ‚Äúgray84‚Äù and ‚Äúgray44‚Äù are being passed to the col= option by using the c() function. Notice how these two colors are used in the resulting bar chart. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to specify additional commands for the barplot function. beside=TRUE beside= can be set to either TRUE or FALSE. When it is TRUE, the bars are clustered side-by-side. When it is set to FALSE, the bars are stacked on top of each other. Typically, beside=TRUE is preferred. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to specify additional commands for the barplot function. legend.text=TRUE legend.text=TRUE allows for the legend to be placed on the barplot. )Closing parenthsis for the barplot function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. Using the table() function. barplot barplot is an R function used to create a bar chart. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. table table is an R function used to tabulate how many times each value occurs in a given dataset. It is being used here to specify the heights of the bars in the bar chart. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. mtcars ‚Äúmtcars‚Äù is a dataset. Type ‚ÄúView(mtcars)‚Äù in R to see it. $ The $ allows us to access any variable from the mtcars dataset. cyl ‚Äúcyl‚Äù is a qualitative variable (in this case actually a numeric vector acting as a qualitative variable) from the ‚Äúmtcars‚Äù dataset. It represents the number of cylinders the vehicle‚Äôs engine has. )Closing parenthsis for the table() function. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the barplot function. col=‚Äúcornsilk‚Äù col= stands for the ‚Äúcolor‚Äù of the plot. The color name ‚Äúcornsilk‚Äù is an available color in R. Type colors() in the R Console to see more options. The color name must always be placed in quotes. )Closing parenthsis for the barplot function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. barplot( barplot is an R function used to create a bar chart. table( table is an R function used to tabulate how many times each pair of values occurs in a given dataset. It is being used here to specify the heights of the bars in this clustered bar chart. mtcars$am ‚Äúmtcars‚Äù is a dataset and the $ sign is being used to access the ‚Äúam‚Äù variable from that dataset. Note that ‚Äúam‚Äù is being used as a qualitative variable, but is actually a numeric vector acting as a qualitative variable. It denotes whether the vehicle is an automatic (0) or manual (1) transmission. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to specify additional variables for the table() function. mtcars$cyl ‚Äúmtcars‚Äù is a dataset and the $ sign is being used to access the ‚Äúcyl‚Äù variable from that dataset. The ‚Äúcyl‚Äù variable gives the cylinders of the vehicle‚Äôs engine as either 4, 6, or 8. So even though it is numeric, it can be used as a qualitative variable. )Closing parenthsis for the table() function. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to start specifying additional commands for the barplot function. beside=TRUEbeside= is an optional command to the barplot() function. When TRUE, the bars are placed next to each other. When FALSE, the bars are stacked on top of each other. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to specify additional commands for the barplot function. col=c(‚Äúfirebrick‚Äù,‚Äúsnow1‚Äù) col= stands for the ‚Äúcolor‚Äù of the plot. The colors of ‚Äúfirebrick‚Äù and ‚Äúsnow1‚Äù are being passed to the col= option using the c() function. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to specify additional commands for the barplot function. legend.text=TRUE legend.text=TRUE allows for the legend to be placed on the barplot. ,¬†The ‚Äú,‚Äù is required to specify additional commands for the barplot function. xlab=‚ÄúCylinders‚Äù xlab= stands for ‚Äúx label.‚Äù Use it to specify the text to print on the plot below the x-axis. The desired text must always be contained in quotes. )Closing parenthsis for the barplot function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. To make a bar chart in R using the ggplot approach, first ensure: library(ggplot2) is loaded. Then, ggplot(data, aes(x=groupsColumn, y=countsColumn) + ¬†¬†geom_bar() data is the name of your dataset. groupsColumn is a column of data from your dataset that is qualitative and represents the groups that should each have a bar in the barplot. countsColumn is a column of data from your dataset that contains the counts of how many times each group has been observed. The aesthetic helper function aes(x= , y=) is how you tell the gpplot to make the x-axis have the values in your groupsColumn of data, the y-axis become your countsColumn. Note if groupsColumn is not a factor, use factor(groupsColumn) instead. The geometry helper function geom_bar() causes the ggplot to become a bar chart. Example Code Manually building the counts data. FarmAnimals <- data.frame(animal = c(‚Äúpigs‚Äù,‚Äúcats‚Äù,‚Äúdogs‚Äù,‚ÄúRoosters‚Äù), count = c(10,5,28,3)) This code creates a data set manually called FarmAnimals using the data.frame() function. Notice that there are two columns in this dataset: ‚Äúanimal‚Äù and ‚Äúcount‚Äù. ggplot An R function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù used to create a framework for a graphic that will have elements added to it with the + sign. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. FarmAnimals ‚ÄúFarmAnimals‚Äù is a dataset we just created. Type ‚ÄúView(FarmAnimals)‚Äù in R after running the above code to see it. ,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function. The space after the comma is not required. It just looks nice. aes( The aes or ‚Äúaesthetics‚Äù function allows you to tell the ggplot how it should appear. This includes things like what the x-axis or y-axis should become. animal,¬† Declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic, the explanatory variable. count,¬† Declares which variable will become the y-axis of the graphic. )Closing parenthsis for the aes function. )Closing parenthsis for the ggplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_col( ) The ‚Äúgeom_col()‚Äù function is being used here instead of ‚Äúgeom_bar()‚Äù because this is a very simple bar chart for just one groups column. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. FarmAnimals <- data.frame(animal = c(‚Äúpigs‚Äù,‚Äúpigs‚Äù,‚Äúcats‚Äù,‚Äúcats‚Äù,‚Äúdogs‚Äù,‚Äúdogs‚Äù,‚ÄúRoosters‚Äù,‚ÄúRoosters‚Äù), count = c(6,4,2,3,18,10,2,1), farm = c(‚Äúfarm1‚Äù,‚Äúfarm2‚Äù,‚Äúfarm1‚Äù,‚Äúfarm2‚Äù,‚Äúfarm1‚Äù,‚Äúfarm2‚Äù,‚Äúfarm1‚Äù,‚Äúfarm2‚Äù)) This code creates a data set manually called FarmAnimals using the data.frame() function. Notice that there are two columns in this dataset: ‚Äúanimal‚Äù and ‚Äúcount‚Äù. ggplot An R function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù used to create a framework for a graphic that will have elements added to it with the + sign. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. FarmAnimals ‚ÄúFarmAnimals‚Äù is a dataset we just created. Type ‚ÄúView(FarmAnimals)‚Äù in R after running the above code to see it. ,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function. The space after the comma is not required. It just looks nice. aes( The aes or ‚Äúaesthetics‚Äù function allows you to tell the ggplot how it should appear. This includes things like what the x-axis or y-axis should become. x = animal,¬† Declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic, the explanatory variable. y = count,¬† Declares which variable will become the y-axis of the graphic. fill = farm,¬† Declares which variable will become the y-axis of the graphic. )Closing parenthsis for the aes function. )Closing parenthsis for the ggplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_bar( The ‚Äúgeom_bar‚Äù function tells the ggplot() to become a bar chart. stat = ‚Äúidentity‚Äù,¬†Tells the ggplot to use the counts as listed in the counts column. position = ‚Äúdodge‚Äù,¬†Causes the bars in the barchart to be side-by-side rather than stacked. color = ‚Äúblack‚Äù,¬†Controls the colors of the borders of the bars in the plot. )Closing parenthsis for the geom_bar() function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. Using an existing dataset directly. ggplot An R function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù used to create a framework for a graphic that will have elements added to it with the + sign. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. mtcars ‚Äúmtcars‚Äù is a dataset in R. Type ‚ÄúView(mtcars)‚Äù in R to see it. ,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function. The space after the comma is not required. It just looks nice. aes( The aes or ‚Äúaesthetics‚Äù function allows you to tell the ggplot how it should appear. This includes things like what the x-axis or y-axis should become. x = factor(cyl) Declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic. Use factor(columnName) when the column consists of numbers to turn it into groups. )Closing parenthsis for the aes function. )Closing parenthsis for the ggplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_bar( The ‚Äúgeom_bar‚Äù function tells the ggplot() to become a bar chart. fill = ‚Äúcornsilk‚Äù,¬†Controls the colors of the insides of the bars in the plot. color = ‚Äúblack‚Äù Controls the colors of the borders of the bars in the plot. )Closing parenthsis for the geom_bar() function. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. ggplot An R function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù used to create a framework for a graphic that will have elements added to it with the + sign. ( Parenthesis to begin the function. Must touch the last letter of the function. mtcars ‚Äúmtcars‚Äù is a dataset in R. Type ‚ÄúView(mtcars)‚Äù in R to see it. ,¬† The comma allows us to specify optional commands to the function. The space after the comma is not required. It just looks nice. aes( The aes or ‚Äúaesthetics‚Äù function allows you to tell the ggplot how it should appear. This includes things like what the x-axis or y-axis should become. x = factor(cyl),¬† Declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic. Use factor(columnName) when the column consists of numbers to turn it into groups. fill = factor(am),¬† Declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic. Use factor(columnName) when the column consists of numbers to turn it into groups. )Closing parenthsis for the aes function. )Closing parenthsis for the ggplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_bar( The ‚Äúgeom_bar‚Äù function tells the ggplot() to become a bar chart. position = ‚Äúdodge‚Äù,¬†Causes the bars to be side-by-side instead of stacked. color = ‚Äúblack‚Äù Controls the colors of the borders of the bars in the plot. )Closing parenthsis for the geom_bar() function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† labs(x=‚ÄúCylinders‚Äù) The ‚Äúlabs‚Äù function is being used to add a title to the x-axis only. title=‚Äúmain title‚Äù and y=‚Äúy title‚Äù could also be used. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. Then, ggplot(data, aes(x=groupsColumn, y=countsColumn) + ¬†¬†geom_bar() data is the name of your dataset. groupsColumn is a column of data from your dataset that is qualitative and represents the groups that should each have a bar in the barplot. countsColumn is a column of data from your dataset that contains the counts of how many times each group has been observed. The aesthetic helper function aes(x= , y=) is how you tell the gpplot to make the x-axis have the values in your groupsColumn of data, the y-axis become your countsColumn. Note if groupsColumn is not a factor, use factor(groupsColumn) instead. The geometry helper function geom_bar() causes the ggplot to become a bar chart. Example Code Manually building the counts data. FarmAnimals <- data.frame(animal = c(‚Äúpigs‚Äù,‚Äúcats‚Äù,‚Äúdogs‚Äù,‚ÄúRoosters‚Äù), count = c(10,5,28,3)) This code creates a data set manually called FarmAnimals using the data.frame() function. Notice that there are two columns in this dataset: ‚Äúanimal‚Äù and ‚Äúcount‚Äù. ggplot An R function ‚Äúggplot‚Äù used to create a framework for a graphic that will have elements added to it with the + sign. This includes things like what the x-axis or y-axis should become. animal,¬† Declares which variable will become the x-axis of the graphic, the explanatory variable. count,¬† Declares which variable will become the y-axis of the graphic. )Closing parenthsis for the aes function. )Closing parenthsis for the ggplot function. ¬†+¬† The addition symbol + is used to add further elements to the ggplot. ¬†¬† geom_col( ) The ‚Äúgeom_col()‚Äù function is being used here instead of ‚Äúgeom_bar()‚Äù because this is a very simple bar chart for just one groups column. ¬†¬†¬†¬†Press Enter to run the code. ¬†‚Ä¶¬† Click to View Output. title: üìç Custom Plots
content: Custom Plots Creativity Required Overview Sometimes no standard plot sufficiently describes the data. In these cases, the only guideline is the one stated originally, ‚Äúthe graphical depiction of data should communicate the truth the data has to offer about the situation of interest.‚Äù R Examples You should add links to examples you find of interesting plots made in R. Here is the R Code for the graphic to the left: plot(density(CO2$uptake[CO2$Type=="Quebec"]), main="", col='skyblue4', xlab="", ylab="", xaxt='n', yaxt='n') lines(density(CO2$uptake[CO2$Type=="Mississippi"]), col='firebrick')
